| MUST | C:/Users/Owner/Documents/process-wiki/process-wiki/Configuration Management Handbook/CM-00 Templates/T-04 Document Templates/Procedure Template.md | 49 | - Simplifying re-work. When data must be reverted to a previous state, the commit messages in the version history help pinpoint the right version to restore. |
| SHOULD | C:/Users/Owner/Documents/process-wiki/process-wiki/Configuration Management Handbook/CM-00 Templates/T-04 Document Templates/Procedure Template.md | 55 | Versions are considered smaller increments of change than other control methods like **revisions** or **baselines**. Since the goal of version control is to produce a comprehensible change history, you should limit the changes in a single version to only a few significant changes or a handful of minor changes. This approach allows an independent reviewer to quickly grasp the evolution of the file. |
| MAY | C:/Users/Owner/Documents/process-wiki/process-wiki/Configuration Management Handbook/CM-00 Templates/T-04 Document Templates/Procedure Template.md | 57 | If you can't summarize the changes in 1-2 sentences in the commit message, the changes may be too complex or dense to be understood in the change history. Revert some of the changes, create a first new version, and then create a second new version with the remaining changes. |
| SHOULD | C:/Users/Owner/Documents/process-wiki/process-wiki/Configuration Management Handbook/CM-00 Templates/T-04 Document Templates/Procedure Template.md | 61 | You should not check out files unless your immediate attention will be devoted to completing the new version. Leaving a file in check-out status for many hours leaves teammates in the dark on your progress, and you may forget what work was left incomplete. Poor version control practice is unprofessional, slows down collaboration, and degrades the quality of the change history (e.g., a version with only a few typo fixes was checked out for 7 hours). Prioritize compl |

This is acceptable so long as the change history is still comprehensible and legibile, **and** the Commit Message for the major version includes an external record ID, such as a **Problem Report** or **Trouble Report**. |

Particularly when scoping changes to assemblies, review any sub-assembly drawings on the Parts List, and all **Where Used** references of the assembly. These details provide full context for analyzing the change. |

The high-level definition of change should be settled on before attempting to resolve Class II or III changes beneath it. |
